title: How I Beautify My PowerShell in Windows Terminal
content:
How I Discover PowerShell

If you’ve used Linux, you will know how useful and attractive a terminal is. Terminal is primitively integrated in Linux and MacOS. You can run command-line instructions(CLI) and shell command in a terminal. What’s more, most Linux releases provide package manager, including apt for Ubuntu Linux, and yum for CentOS.MacOS, a UNIX-like OS, has homebrew. However, Windows is originated from DOS . It does not support shell commands at first. It was not until the year 2006 when Microsoft released its first version of Windows PowerShell. It is developed based on .NET Framework. Since then, PowerShell has published 6 versions, the latest of which is 5.1. On Aug 18th, 2016, Microsoft announced that PowerShell can be run on MacOS and Linux.

When I first got to learn to program C, I downloaded gcc compiler as a part of MingGW. MinGW provides solely an access to the functionality of the Microsoft C runtime and some language-specific runtimes, unlike Cygwin. The latter provide a POSIX runtime environment for POSIX application deployment on Windows. As what GNU suggested, I installed MSYS2, a command-line interpreter system that gives a general purpose command line environment.

Just as what MSYS2 itself claims, “MSYS2 provides a minimal shell required to run auto-tools and other build systems which get the source for software from the Internet from different repositories, configure them and build them. The shell and core tools exist mainly to allow porting Unix programs to run natively on Windows”.^1

(The file separator / really tricks me to believe MSYS2 simulates a Linux environment at first)

You can customize the font and color themes of MSYS2 just like I do. I turned down the opacity of the background, and set the font to JetBrainsMono. MYSYS2 allows users to install a few plugins through package manager Pacman. Don’t expect that it can do the same thing as in Arch Linux. I can’t even install figlet. And just as mentioned above, it supports few Linux shell command. It may be useful if your only goal is to run gcc. At least you don’t have to tolerate with the ugly cmd terminal.

I then sought for better options. I then got to know cmder. It is barely a console terminal. Frankly speaking, I attempted to download it from https://cmder.org for a few times. However, the poor network access prompted me to give up.

It was then I heard of PowerShell. PowerShell’s original terminal does look as ugly as cmd. Despite this, it differs from cmd who runs DOS command. PowerShell can do a lot things what cmd can’t. It is easier, object-oriented, and C#-backed. PowerShell could be really Powerful. You can run ssh, nc(clone module PowerCat from here and set its alias to nc), you name it! I discovered Windows Terminal and WSL shortly afterwards.

Beautiful PowerShell in Windows Terminal

This is how my PowerShell looks like now in Windows Terminal.

How To Beautify Your PowerShell in Windows Terminal

  1. Install Windows Terminal. It should be free to download in Microsoft Store.

  2. Install Scoop. Scoop, just like chocolatey, is a package manager for Windows. I use it to download Nerd-Fonts for Windows Terminal. Detailed information can be found on Github. If you’re not familiar with English instructions, you may refer to this article.

  3. Install proper fonts. After setting up Scoop, open Windows Terminal. It should open PowerShell by default. Importing fonts to Windows may need administrator permission, so I suggest you run Windows Terminal in Admin Mode. Type in scoop search JetBrainsMono-NF. It should prompt you to add bucket nerd-fonts: scoop bucket add nerd-fonts. Then scoop install JetBrainsMono-NF, and wait a minute or so until the install process finish. You may install the font you want and import them in the next step.

  4. Change Windows Terminal outlook. By clicking the more button on the navigation bar of Windows Terminal or by hitting keys ctrl+,, you will find Settings of Windows Terminal.

  1. Install oh-my-posh. oh-my-posh is almost equivalent to oh-my-zsh on *nix system. It provides many built-in themes and supports command auto-completion. You can download and install oh-my-posh on https://github.com/JanDeDobbeleer/oh-my-posh, where explicitly listed each procedures. The best way is to install it through Scoop.

  1. Set your own oh-my-posh theme. Classical themes like Agnoster and Robbyrussell is built-in. Mine is edited over the version from Github user Spencewooo‘s. If you want to use my theme, place the following Michaelfyc.psm1 file under theme directory of oh-my-posh.

Steps below are alternatives. You can decide to implement them or not yourself.

  1. We tend to be familiar with the bash command in *nux system rather than PowerShell. Never mind, PowerShell provides Set-alias function to help programmers better use of it. Most common commands like ls and cat are set aliases by default. You can set your own one. Similar to oh-my-zsh, whose aliases configuration is written in .zshrc, PowerShell aliases can be written in a specified file.

    You may customize your own aliases using this method. It is one of the motives that pushes me to learn PowerShell programming.

  2. Some packages seem unavailable on Scoop, including fortune and lolcat. Don’t worry. Remember what I said about PowerShell? It’s C#-backed. In fact, besides Scoop, we have PowerShellGet. Take fortune as example, you can search for it on https://www.powershellgallery.com/ when Scoop doesn’t help.

You may find a module called Get-Quote that does the same thing as command fortune. In PowerShell, enter Install-Module Get-Quote (under admin mode..). Set alias of Get-Quotes to fortune like what is done in step 8. fortune is now to go!
